latest news.eng_title: Boeing and striking factory workers to resume mediated talks on Tuesday
latest news.summary: Boeing and striking US factory workers will resume mediated talks on Tuesday under a federal mediator, after workers voted overwhelmingly to reject a 25% wage hike proposal from the company. The union, IAM-District 751, said 'Now is the moment to rise - show Boeing that our voices aren't just loud; they are unstoppable.' The strike, which began on Friday, has shuttered two major plane assembly plants in the Puget Sound region, further delaying Boeing's turnaround efforts. Workers rejected the proposal with 94.6% of the vote, and voted to strike with 96%. The last strike, in 2008, lasted 57 days.
latest news.title: Boeing and striking factory workers to resume mediated talks on Tuesday

latest news.eng_title: Boeing Workers in US Go on Strike for Better Wages
latest news.summary: Boeing workers in the US went on strike for better wages. The union announced that talks between Boeing and striking workers in US factories will resume on Tuesday under a federal mediator, after workers overwhelmingly rejected a proposal from the struggling aviation giant. 'On Tuesday, the union will meet with federal mediators assigned through the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service (FMCS) and Boeing to begin negotiations,' said the IAM-Distrito 751 union chapter, which represents over 33,000 union members in the Seattle region. Boeing did not immediately respond to a request for comment from AFP. Since the strike began on Friday over a salary dispute, the company has said it is eager to return to the negotiating table. Union leaders called the strike shortly after workers in the Seattle region, in the Pacific Northwest, rejected the provisional contract offer with 94.6% of the vote and voted in favor of the strike with 96%. The last strike, in 2008, lasted 57 days. Federal mediators had said on Friday night that talks would resume early next week, but did not specify a date. 'Now is the time to stand up and show Boeing that our voices are not only strong, but unstoppable,' said the IAM-Distrito 751 union. 'Let our presence at the picket lines be felt across the country and beyond. We are stronger than ever and we will not give up.' The strike closed two major aircraft assembly plants in the Puget Sound region, further delaying the company's recovery efforts, which are facing financial difficulties. Boeing, led by new CEO Kelly Ortberg, had hoped that a 25% salary increase over four years and a commitment to invest in the Puget Sound region would be enough. But base workers described it as a slap in the face after more than a decade of nearly stagnant wages.'
latest news.title: EEUU: trabajadores de Boeing en huelga por mejoras salariales

latest news.eng_title: Boeing strike could go on for a while, union leader says: Report

Organization: International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers

latest news.summary: More than 30,000 Boeing workers, members of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers (IAM), began a strike on Friday after voting down a new contract. Union leader Jon Holden stated, 'A strike at Boeing could go on for a while' as workers are seeking bigger wage increases and an improved pension. The IAM workers produce Boeing's top-selling 737 MAX and other jets in Seattle and Portland.
latest news.title: Boeing strike could go on for a while, union leader says: Report

latest news.eng_title: Ending the Boeing strike won't be easy. Here's why.

Organization: International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers

latest news.summary: The Boeing strike, which began on Friday, is a result of the company's proposed labor contract being rejected by thousands of employees. The union, International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, is now negotiating with Boeing management to reach a better deal. Labor experts say the strength of the strike vote, 96% in favor, gives the union leverage in negotiations. Boeing is in a difficult financial situation, with a slowdown in commercial jet production and significant losses, but labor experts say the company can afford to improve its offer. The main issues in the strike are wages and retirement benefits, with employees seeking a 40% wage increase and the return of a pension plan. Boeing has offered to raise wages by 25% on average and let workers carry over higher wage rates when switching jobs. However, union members are firm in their demands, with one mechanic saying, 'We are firm on that.' The strike comes at a critical time for Boeing's finances and reputation, and labor experts say the company's order backlog and solid market position make it strong in the long run.
latest news.title: Ending the Boeing strike won't be easy. Here's why.

latest news.eng_title: Boeing Factory Workers Go on Strike Over Proposed Contract

Organization: International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers
Title: CEO
Press Secretary

latest news.summary: 33,000 Boeing factory workers went on strike on Friday, September 13, 2024, after rejecting a proposed contract that would have increased their salary by 25% over four years. The workers, who are members of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers (IAM), voted 94.6% against the proposal, which also included a $3,000 signing bonus and reduced healthcare costs. The union's negotiating committee supported the strike and voted 96% in favor. The workers are demanding a 40% salary increase over three years and the restoration of traditional pensions, which were abolished 10 years ago. Boeing's CEO, Brian West, said the company is 'prepared to return to the negotiating table to reach a new agreement.' The strike is expected to cost Boeing a significant source of revenue, as airlines pay a large portion of the purchase price when they take delivery of a new plane. Boeing's total debt is approximately $60 billion. The company is seeking ways to conserve its liquidity, according to West. The White House has also weighed in, with Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre saying that administration officials have contacted Boeing and the unions. 'We think they should negotiate in good faith and work towards an agreement that gives employees the benefits they deserve. This would also strengthen the company,' she said.
latest news.title: Grève de Boeing : 33 000 ouvriers d'usine quittent leur travail en raison de leurs salaires

latest news.eng_title: Boeing strike could drag on as workers push for higher wages, union...
latest news.summary: A strike at Boeing could continue for an extended period as workers, led by union leader Jon Holden, push for higher wages and an improved pension. Holden stated, 'We have the most leverage and the most power at the most opportune time that we've ever had in our history, and our members are expecting us to use it.' The union members, who produce Boeing's top-selling 737 MAX and other jets, rejected a new contract that included a 25% pay rise over four years due to the removal of a performance bonus, which they claim would erode half of the headline salary increase. Boeing's stock fell 3.7% on Friday, and a long strike could further damage the company's finances, which are already strained by a $60 billion debt pile.
latest news.title: Boeing strike could drag on as workers push for higher wages, union...

latest news.summary: A strike at Boeing could continue for an extended period as workers, led by union leader Jon Holden, are confident they can secure larger wage increases and an improved pension. The strike, which began on Friday, involves over 30,000 members of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers (IAM) who produce Boeing's top-selling 737 MAX and other jets in Seattle and Portland. According to Holden, 'workers are confident they can get bigger wage increases and an improved pension'.

latest news.eng_title: Striking Boeing factory workers say they are ready to hold out for a better contract
latest news.summary: 33,000 Boeing machinists went on strike on Friday, rejecting a proposed contract that would have raised their wages by 25% over four years. The strike is expected to shut down production of Boeing's best-selling jetliners, adding to the company's financial losses and damaged reputation. According to the article, the strike will not disrupt airline flights, but it will have a significant impact on Boeing's production. 'The strike by 33,000 machinists will not disrupt airline flights anytime soon, but it is expected to shut down production of Boeing's best-selling jetliners,' said the article. This marks yet another setback for the company, which is already dealing with billions of dollars in financial losses.
latest news.title: Striking Boeing factory workers say they are ready to hold out for a better contract

latest news.source_id: الموقع الرسمي لجريدة عمان - الصفحة الرئيسية
latest news.eng_title: Boeing Employees Go on Strike, Halting Production in Seattle
latest news.summary: Tens of thousands of Boeing employees went on strike on Friday, a move unprecedented in 16 years, halting production at its main site in the Seattle area. The strike began after workers rejected a new agreement proposed by the American aircraft manufacturer after eight days of negotiations between the company's management and the local branch of the Machinists' Union. The new agreement would replace one that expired 16 years ago and ended on Thursday night. According to John Holden, the president of the Machinists' Union, who represents around 33,000 of the company's 170,000 employees at the coastal site in northwestern United States, the workers rejected the agreement announced on September 8 by 94.6%, and voted in favor of the strike by 96%. Holden said at a press conference on Thursday, 'The strike will begin at midnight.' He also announced a lawsuit against Boeing at the Federal Agency responsible for workers' rights due to the company's unfair practices during the negotiations. The last strike in the group was in 2008 and lasted 57 days. However, Holden said he cannot 'guarantee more through the strike.' The strike on Friday led to the closure of two major aircraft assembly plants in the cities of Renton and Everett, producing 737 Max and 777 and 767 cargo planes, which were originally delayed in delivery. Production also stopped at other sites, including a parts factory in Portland, Oregon, and a site for re-manufacturing dozens of 787 Dreamliner aircraft in Everett, which has been operational for several months. However, the production of Dreamliner aircraft is not currently affected as the factory is located in South Carolina (East) and is not included in the strike. Boeing receives the largest payments, around 60%, when the planes are delivered. The company is also subject to more oversight and its production has slowed down since the incident involving an Alaska Airlines 737 Max 9 plane that lost a door while in flight in early January. According to the aviation news site 'Leeham News', 'The strike is the last thing Boeing needs, which is struggling financially.' Analysts at TD Cowen estimate that a 50-day strike would deprive Boeing of $3 billion to $3.5 billion in liquidity. Boeing's shares fell by 2.66% on the New York Stock Exchange. Despite the strike decision, the management announced in a statement, 'We are committed to restoring our relationship with our employees and the union, and we are ready to return to the negotiating table to reach a new agreement.' The new CEO, Kelly Orourke, promised after a week of taking office on August 8 to work on improving the relationship with the union. The rejected agreement includes a 25% increase in wages over four years, as well as a commitment to invest in the Seattle area, and also the construction of a new plane to be produced in 2035, which would provide job opportunities for several decades. Boeing had hoped that these concessions would be enough to avoid the strike, given its unstable financial situation due to the crash of two 737 Max 8 planes in 2018 and 2019, killing 346 people, as well as numerous quality control issues. Kelly Orourke, who replaced Dave Calhoun as CEO last month, said, 'It's no secret that our business is going through a difficult period, partly due to our past mistakes... The strike will hinder the group's and its employees' recovery.' He urged employees not to 'give up' on the expected progress in the future due to 'past disappointments.' However, the workers consider the proposed wage increase to be too low, and the proposed pension plan to be unacceptable. Cami Brian, who has worked at Boeing for 18 years, said to AFP after the vote in favor of the strike, 'We were sold cheap... We cannot accept these crumbs they offer us and be grateful.' She referred to the large salary of the company's president. Paul Janosik, a 55-year-old electrician who has worked at Boeing for 13 years, said that the proposed increase in his salary would be only around 9% when considering the elimination of the annual bonus. He added that the increase would not be enough to cover the cost of living.
latest news.title: توقف انتاج شركة بوينغ لطائرات جزئيا بسبب أول إضراب عمّالي منذ 16 عاما

latest news.eng_title: Boeing factory workers go on strike
latest news.summary: Aircraft assembly workers at Boeing factories near Seattle went on strike after 94.6% of union members rejected a tentative contract that would have increased wages by 25% over four years. The strike involves 33,000 Boeing machinists and is expected to shut down production of the company's best-selling airline planes. The machinists make $75,608 per year on average, and the proposed contract would have raised their pay to $106,350 at the end of the four-year contract. However, the union wanted a 40% pay raise over three years and the restoration of traditional pensions, which were not included in the proposed contract. Boeing CEO Kelly Ortberg said the company is 'ready to get back to the table to reach a new agreement' and that a strike would put the company's recovery in jeopardy. IAM District 751 President Jon Holden said the strike is about 'respect, the past, and fighting for our future.' The strike is expected to deprive Boeing of much-needed cash from delivering new planes to airlines. 'This is about respect, this is about the past, and this is about fighting for our future,' Holden said in announcing the strike.
latest news.title: Boeing factory workers go on strike

news knowledge.eng_title: Boeing Employees Go on Strike for the First Time in 16 Years
news knowledge.summary: Thousands of Boeing employees went on strike (starting on Friday), halting production at its Seattle-area facility for the first time in 16 years. The strike began after workers rejected a new agreement proposed by the American aircraft manufacturer group following negotiations that lasted since March 8 between the company's management and the local branch of the mechanics' union. The new agreement would replace the one that expired 16 years ago and ended on Thursday night. According to John Holden, the president of the mechanics' union in the region, who represents around 33,000 employees at the company's coastal facility in northwestern United States, out of 170,000 employees in the Boeing group, workers rejected the announced agreement on September 8 by 94.6%, and voted in favor of the strike by 96%. Holden said in a press conference, 'The strike will begin at midnight.' The union also filed a lawsuit against Boeing before a federal agency responsible for workers' rights due to the company's unfair practices during the negotiations. The last strike in the group dates back to 2008 and lasted for 57 days. However, Holden said he cannot 'guarantee more through the strike.' The strike on Friday morning led to the closure of two major aircraft assembly plants in the cities of Renton and Everett, producing 737 Max and 777 and 767 cargo planes that have been delayed in delivery. Production also stopped at other sites, including a parts factory in Portland, Oregon, and a facility for re-manufacturing dozens of 787 Dreamliners in Everett, which has been operational for several months. However, Dreamliner assembly has not been affected as the factory is located in South Carolina and is not part of the strike. Boeing receives the largest payments, around 60%, when delivering the planes. The company is also subject to more scrutiny and its production has slowed down since the incident involving an Alaska Airlines 737 Max 9 that lost a door while in flight in early January. According to the 'Leeham News' website, which specializes in aviation news, 'the strike is the last thing Boeing needs, which is struggling financially.' Analysts at TD Cowen estimate that a 50-day strike would deprive Boeing of $3 billion to $3.5 billion in liquidity. As of 14:00 GMT, Boeing's shares fell by 2.66% on the New York Stock Exchange. Despite the strike decision, the management announced in a statement, 'We are committed to restoring our relationships with our employees and the union, and we are ready to return to the negotiating table to reach a new agreement.' The company's new president, Kelly Ortberg, promised to improve relations with the union after a week of taking office on August 8. The rejected agreement includes a 25% increase in wages over four years, as well as a commitment to invest in the Seattle area, and also the construction of a new plane expected to be produced in 2035, which would provide job opportunities for several decades. Boeing had hoped that these incentives would be enough to avoid the strike, while its financial situation is unstable due to the crash of two 737 Max 8 planes in 2018 and 2019, killing 346 people, as well as numerous quality production issues. In the evening of Wednesday, Kelly Ortberg said that 'it is no secret that our business is going through a difficult period, and this is partly due to our past mistakes... the strike will hinder the group's and its employees' recovery.' He urged employees not to 'give up' on the expected progress due to 'past disappointments.' However, workers consider the proposed wage increase too low, and the proposed pension plan unacceptable. Cami Brain, who has worked at Boeing for 18 years, told AFP after the vote in favor of the strike, 'We were sold cheap... we cannot accept these crumbs they offer us and be grateful for them,' referring to the large salary of the company's president. Paul Janosik, an electrician, said that Boeing's offer was 'misleading... they are talking about a 25% increase, but this is not the case.'
news knowledge.title: إضراب غير مسبوق يعطل إنتاج بوينغ لأول مرة منذ 16 عاماً

news knowledge.eng_title: Thousands of Boeing Employees Go on Strike, Halting Production
news knowledge.summary: Thousands of Boeing employees went on strike on Friday, a move unprecedented since 16 years ago, halting production at its headquarters in the Seattle area. The strike began after workers rejected a new agreement proposed by the American aircraft manufacturer after negotiations with the local union of mechanics since March 8. The new agreement would replace an existing one that expired on September 8. According to John Holden, the president of the local union of mechanics, who represents around 33,000 employees at the company's coastal facility in northwestern United States, out of a total of 170,000 employees in the Boeing group, workers rejected the announced agreement on September 8 by 94.6%, and voted in favor of the strike by 96%. Holden said in a press conference on Thursday evening, 'The strike will begin at midnight.' The union has also filed a lawsuit against Boeing at a federal agency responsible for workers' rights due to the company's unfair practices during the negotiations. The last strike in the group dates back to 2008 and lasted for 57 days. However, Holden said he cannot 'guarantee more through the strike.' The strike led to the closure of two main aircraft assembly plants in the cities of Renton and Everett, producing 737 Max and 777 and 767 cargo planes, which were originally delayed in delivery. Production has also stopped at other sites, including a parts factory in Portland, Oregon, and a facility for re-manufacturing dozens of 787 Dreamliner aircraft in Everett, which has been operational for several months. However, Dreamliner assembly operations are not currently affected as the factory is located in South Carolina (East) and is not covered by the strike. 'Complexity' The situation becomes more complex as Boeing receives the largest payments, around 60% of the agreed-upon amounts, when the planes are delivered. The company is also subject to further oversight and has slowed its production since the incident involving an Alaska Airlines 737 Max 9 plane that lost a door while in flight in early January. According to the aviation news site 'Leeham News,' the strike is the last thing Boeing, which is struggling financially, needs. Analysts at TD Cowen estimate that a 50-day strike would deprive Boeing of $3 billion to $3.5 billion in liquidity. At around 14:00 GMT, Boeing's shares fell by 2.66% on the New York Stock Exchange. Despite the strike decision, the administration announced in a statement, 'We are committed to restoring our relationship with our employees and the union, and we are ready to return to the negotiating table to reach a new agreement.' The new CEO, Kelly Orger, promised after a week of taking office on August 8 to work on improving the relationship with the union. The rejected agreement includes a 25% increase in wages over four years, as well as a commitment to invest in the Seattle area, and also the construction of a new aircraft expected to be produced in 2035, which would provide job opportunities for several decades. Boeing had hoped that these incentives would be enough to avoid the strike, given its unstable financial situation due to the crash of two 737 Max 8 planes in 2018 and 2019, killing 346 people, as well as numerous quality production issues. In the evening of Wednesday, Kelly Orger, who replaced Dave Calhoun as CEO last month, said, 'It's no secret that our work is going through a difficult period, partly due to our past mistakes.... The strike will hinder the group's and its employees' recovery.' He urged employees not to 'give up' on the expected progress due to 'past setbacks.' However, workers consider the proposed wage increase to be far too low, and the proposed pension plan to be unacceptable. Cami Bryan, who has worked at Boeing for 18 years, told AFP after the vote in favor of the strike, 'We were sold cheaply... We cannot accept these crumbs they offer us and be grateful to them' referring to the large salary of the company's CEO. Paul Janosik, a 55-year-old electrician who has worked at Boeing for 13 years, said the offer made by Boeing was 'misleading... They talk about a 25% increase, but this is not the case.' He added that the increase on his salary would be only around 9% when considering the elimination of the annual bonus.

The vote to reject the contract was 94.6 percent, and the vote to strike was 96 percent. news knowledge.eng_title: Boeing Workers in US Go on Strike

news knowledge.summary: The union representing Boeing aircraft factory workers in the US announced the start of a strike from September 13, 2024. Members of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers in Seattle, Washington, voted to reject a 25% salary increase proposal over 4 years and to halt activities at the factories. According to the union, 94.6% voted against the agreement and 96% approved the strike, exceeding the 2/3 majority required for the measure to take effect. The strike involves 33,000 Boeing machinists, mostly in the state of Washington, and will likely halt commercial aircraft production, as reported by CBS. The strike will not affect flights but will contribute to the Boeing's reputation crisis, particularly regarding the safety of its 737 Max aircraft, which have been questioned since two crashes in 2018 and 2019 killed 346 people, as said, 'It was a great day.'

The workers, who produce Boeing's 737 MAX and other jets in the Seattle and Portland areas, were voting on their first full contract in 16 years. According to IAM leadership, the workers had previously recommended accepting the contract, but many workers were unhappy with the terms, particularly the lack of a 40% pay rise and the loss of an annual bonus. As one union member said, 'On Strike Against Boeing.'

The walkout, starting at midnight on Friday, will affect 33,000 workers across the US West Coast, crippling manufacturing at Boeing's Seattle commercial jet hub. This is the first strike since 2008 and adds to the company's woes, which include investigations, customer backlash, and an executive shake-up following a near-catastrophe at the start of 2024. As one might expect, the strike will put further strain on the planemaker.
news knowledge.title: Boeing Factory Staff Reject Contract, Will Strike From Midnight

news knowledge.eng_title: Boeing assembly workers vote on whether to strike or approve contract offer
news knowledge.summary: Boeing's 33,000 aircraft assembly workers, mostly in the Seattle area, are set to vote on whether to approve a contract offer that includes 25% pay raises over four years. If the workers reject the contract and two-thirds of them vote to strike, a work stoppage would begin on Friday at 12:01 a.m. Pacific time. New CEO Kelly Ortberg made a last-ditch effort to avert a strike, saying 'no one wins' in a walkout. He emphasized that a strike would put the company's recovery in jeopardy and further erode trust with customers. Although the bargaining committee recommended ratification, IAM District 751 President Jon Holden predicted earlier that workers would vote to strike. A strike would stop production of the 737 Max, 777, and 767 cargo plane at factories in Everett and Renton, Washington, but likely would not affect the Boeing 787 Dreamliners built by nonunion workers in South Carolina. Aerospace analyst Cai von Rumohr estimated that a strike lasting into mid-November could cost Boeing up to $3.5 billion in cash flow.
news knowledge.title: Boeing assembly workers vote on whether to strike or approve contract offer

news knowledge.eng_title: Boeing's union of factory workers is set to vote on a strike
news knowledge.summary: Boeing's 33,000 aircraft assembly workers, mostly in the Seattle area, are set to vote on a contract offer that includes 25% pay raises over four years. If the workers reject the contract and two-thirds of them vote to strike, a work stoppage would begin Friday at 12:01 a.m. PDT. New CEO Kelly Ortberg made a last-ditch effort to avert a strike, saying, 'no one wins' in a walkout. However, IAM District 751 President Jon Holden predicted earlier this week that workers would vote to strike, citing complaints about the deal on social media. A strike would stop production of the 737 Max, 777, and 767 cargo plane at factories in Everett and Renton, Washington, but likely would not affect Boeing 787 Dreamliners. TD Cowen aerospace analyst Cai von Rumohr estimated that a strike lasting into mid-November could cost Boeing up to $3.5 billion in cash flow.
